<Summary source="https://www.ch-aviation.com/news/163761-airbus-records-49-orders-in-january-2026">
## Summary of Article

**Disclaimer**: The extracted content appears to be primarily a subscription/promotional page with limited substantive information about the headline topic.

### Key Information:

**Fact:**
- Airbus recorded 49 orders in January 2026

**Limitations:**
The article content provided is mostly promotional material for ch-aviation's data and news subscription services. The headline mentions "49 orders in January 2026" but the extracted text does not contain any additional details, context, or analysis about these orders. Critically, the article does not mention **deliveries** for January or February 2026, which is the focus of the forecasting question.

**Note**: Orders and deliveries are distinct metrics - orders represent new purchase commitments while deliveries represent actual aircraft handed over to customers. This article only addresses orders, not deliveries.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.scramble.nl/civil-news/airbus-january-2026-orders-deliveries">
## Summary of Article

**Source:** Scramble.nl  
**Date:** February 09, 2026  
**Author:** Anton Homma

### Key Facts and Statistics:

**January 2026 Airbus Performance:**
- **Total Orders:** 49 aircraft
- **Total Deliveries:** 19 aircraft

**Orders Breakdown:**
- 1 A330-900 (Air Algérie)
- 8 A320 neos (IAG)
- 6 A321 neos (IAG)
- 24 A320 neos (Spring Airlines)
- 6 A321 neos (Spring Airlines)
- 8 A321 neos (Undisclosed customers)

**Deliveries Breakdown (19 total):**
- 1 A321 neo (Aer Lingus)
- 1 A220-300 (Air Canada)
- 1 A220-300 (Air France)
- 1 A220-300 (Breeze Airways)
- 1 A320 neo (Condor)
- 1 A320 neo (Frontier Airlines)
- 1 A320 neo (Hainan Airlines)
- 1 A320 neo (IndiGo)
- 1 A320 neo (Jetstar Airways)
- 1 A320 neo (Royal Jordanian)
- 1 A350-900 (Swiss)
- 2 A321 neos (Turkish Airlines)
- 3 A321 neos (United Airlines)
- 1 A321 neo (VietJet Air)
- 2 A321 neos (Wizz Air)

### Relevance to Forecasting Question:

This article provides January 2026 delivery data (19 aircraft) but does not contain information about **February 2026** deliveries, which is the specific month being forecasted. The January data may serve as a baseline or reference point for understanding Airbus's early 2026 delivery performance.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://simpleflying.com/boeing-crushes-airbus-orders-deliveries/">
# Summary of Article: "Boeing Crushes Airbus In Orders & Deliveries: A Dominant Start To 2026"

**Source:** Simple Flying  
**Date:** February 10, 2026  
**Author:** Victoria Agronsky

## Key Facts and Statistics Relevant to the Question:

### Airbus January 2026 Deliveries:
- **Total deliveries: 19 commercial aircraft**
- Breakdown by aircraft type:
  - 15 A320neo family aircraft
  - 3 A220 aircraft
  - 1 A350 aircraft

### Airbus January 2026 Orders:
- Fewer than 50 net orders during January 2026

### Comparative Context (Boeing):
- Boeing delivered 46 commercial jets in January 2026 (38 Boeing 737 MAX, 5 787 Dreamliners, and a few other models)
- Boeing recorded 103 net orders in January 2026 (107 commitments minus 4 cancellations)

## Additional Context:
- The article notes that Airbus delivered more aircraft overall in 2025 than Boeing, despite Boeing's improved performance
- Airbus continues to hold a larger long-term backlog
- Airbus is taking an incremental approach in 2026, emphasizing supply-chain stability and gradual rate increases
- The global commercial aviation sector remains supply-constrained due to production limitations across engines, components, and labor

## Note:
This article provides data for **January 2026 only**. The forecasting question asks about **February 2026** deliveries, which are not covered in this article.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://simpleflying.com/airbus-boeing-rule-air-2026/">
# Summary of "Airbus Vs. Boeing: Who Will Rule The Air In 2026?"

**Source:** Simple Flying, January 17, 2026, by Victoria Agronsky

## Key Facts and Statistics:

### Delivery Projections for 2026:
- **Airbus:** Projected to deliver roughly **900 to 1,044 aircraft** in 2026
- **Boeing:** Target of approximately **708 units** in 2026
- The delivery gap between the two manufacturers is nearly **200 aircraft**

### Production Rates and Targets:
- **Airbus:** Opening new final assembly lines in Tianjin and Toulouse to reach a production rate of **75 aircraft per month by 2027**
- **Boeing:** Currently capped at production in the **mid-40s per month** for 2026, specifically mentioned as **42 aircraft per month**

### Market Position:
- Airbus enters 2026 with its **largest backlog in history**
- Boeing has taken the lead in **new orders for the first time in 6 years**
- Combined Airbus and Boeing order books are approaching **15,000 aircraft**
- Industry-wide load factor is at a record **84%**

### Specific Aircraft Milestones:
- IndiGo took delivery of its first **A321 XLR in the first week of January 2026**
- United Airlines is expecting its first **Airbus A321 XLRs** to replace aging Boeing 757-200s

## Key Challenges and Constraints:

### Airbus:
- **Pratt & Whitney GTF engine crisis:** Nearly **one-third of the global A320neo fleet** remains grounded or in storage due to Geared Turbofan powder metal defects
- Engine turnaround times at maintenance centers have ballooned from **60 days to over 300 days**
- Many delivered aircraft are being dismantled for parts or parked immediately after delivery due to lack of serviceable engines

### Boeing:
- **Boeing 777X:** First delivery officially pushed to **2027**, following a **$4.9 billion charge in late 2025** linked to certification setbacks
- Awaiting regulatory certification for the **737 MAX 7, 737 MAX 10, and 777X**
- Operating under **FAA oversight** and quality re-baselining requirements
- Expected to turn **sustainably cash-flow positive for the first time since the pre-MAX crisis** in 2026

### Both Manufacturers:
- Supply chain fragility affecting seats, cabin fixtures, and raw titanium availability

## Named Source Opinions:

- **Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury:** Pointed out that aircraft orders are frequently shaped by geopolitical dynamics and trade negotiations rather than pure market demand
- **Boeing CEO Kelly Ortberg:** Stated that Boeing will not prioritize speed over quality, emphasizing a multiyear cultural change required at the company
- **United Airlines CEO Scott Kirby:** Teased surprises for 2026 in a January 2nd memo, including debut of new Polaris Studio premium cabin on Boeing 787-9

## General Industry Sentiment (less specific sourcing):

- **Air Insight** notes Boeing has taken the lead in new orders for the first time in 6 years, signaling airline confidence is shifting back toward a more balanced duopoly
- Financial and aviation analysts view 2026 as a "reset year" rather than a definitive victory for either side
- Industry consensus: 2026 is the year when delivery certainty finally outweighs brand preference

## Competitive Landscape:

- **COMAC C919:** Has over **1,000 orders** on its books and is making inroads in Southeast Asia (e.g., Gallop Air in Brunei) and Brazil
- **Embraer:** Remains a strong niche player with its E2 family at the lower end of the capacity scale

**Note:** This article provides 2026 annual projections but does not contain specific monthly delivery data for February 2026.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://mexicobusiness.news/aerospace/news/airbus-delays-a220-production-amid-supply-chain-challenges">
# Summary of Article: Airbus Delays A220 Production Amid Supply Chain Challenges

**Source:** Mexico Business  
**Date:** October 30, 2025

## Key Facts and Statistics:

1. **Current A220 Production Rate:** 7-8 aircraft per month

2. **Production Targets:**
   - Official goal: 14 A220s per month in 2026
   - Internal planning suggests this rate may not be reached until December 2026
   - Internal milestone: 12 per month by mid-2026

3. **Production Delays:**
   - Multiple A220 aircraft removed from 2025 production schedule
   - Nearly 10 aircraft removed from 2026 schedule (according to three industry sources cited by Reuters)

4. **2025 Delivery Performance:**
   - 62 A220 aircraft delivered in first nine months of 2025
   - Internal target: 100 A220 deliveries for full year 2025 (one-third higher than 2024)
   - Total Airbus commercial aircraft delivery target for 2025: 820 units

5. **Financial Impact:**
   - Quebec wrote down C$400 million (US$286 million) on its 25% stake in the A220 program
   - Airbus owns remaining 75%
   - A220 program has not yet reached profitability since acquisition from Bombardier in 2018

## Key Issues Identified:

- Ongoing supply chain constraints affecting both Montreal (Canada) and Mobile (Alabama, US) facilities
- Parts shortages, production errors, and limited supplier capacity
- Wing shortages linked to Spirit AeroSystems in Belfast
- Engine and component shortages

## Named Source Opinion:

- **Quebec Economy Minister Christine Frechette** attributed losses to "trade tensions and fragile supply chains"

## Less Reliable/Unnamed Sources:

- Three industry sources told Reuters about the production schedule removals
- Two sources confirmed former Airbus Canada CEO Benoit Schultz's internal target of 100 A220 deliveries in 2025
- One source noted ongoing wing shortages
</Summary>

**Whitaker: U.S. F-35 Deliveries to Europe to Reach 600 Soon**
At the Munich Security Conference, U.S. NATO Permanent Representative Matthew Whitaker stated that the number of F-35 fighter jets delivered by the United States to its European allies will soon reach 600. He emphasized that he does not view the current risk as stemming from a potential U.S. decision by President Donald Trump to halt F-35 deliveries, but rather from the possibility that allied nations may choose not to purchase them. The statement was made on February 14, 2026, according to Azeri - Press Informasiya Agentliyi.

**With a trading volume of EUR 167.9 mn AIR.PA trades 1.7 percent higher today**
Airbus (AIR.PA) traded 1.7% higher over a 24-hour period ending at 11:17 PM Central Europe on Friday, February 13, 2026, with a current stock price of EUR 190.42. The company's trading volume reached EUR 167.9 million in the past 24 hours, and the total supply of Airbus shares is 792.3 million. Airbus has a market capitalization of EUR 150.2 billion. Since the end of last month, Airbus shares have declined by 11.62%. The 200-day simple moving average is EUR 188.5. The 52-week high was EUR 221.3 on January 14, 2026, and the 52-week low was EUR 126.4 on April 7, 2025. Airbus SE extended its multi-year partnership with data-analytics firm Palantir, renewing a collaboration that has lasted over a decade. The renewed agreement supports the Skywise aviation data platform, aiming to improve fleet management, maintenance, and data integration across commercial and military aircraft portfolios. Despite a modest recent uptick in stock price, analysts caution that delivery figures and broader market conditions may affect investor sentiment. Airbus continues to trade on NYSE Euronext Paris and serves global markets as a leading European aerospace and defense manufacturer, producing commercial and military aircraft, helicopters, missiles, satellites, defense systems, and offering conversion and maintenance services. The company went public on July 10, 2000.

**WDS 2026 highlights Saudi push to become major aerospace hub - AeroTime**
The 3rd edition of the World Defense Show (WDS) took place in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, from February 8–12, 2026, marking the largest event yet with 1,400 companies from 89 countries occupying 27,500 square meters across four fully booked exhibition halls—representing a 58% increase over the 2022 inaugural edition. The event highlighted Saudi Arabia’s strategic goal to become a major aerospace and defense industrial hub. Ahmed Al-Ohali, Governor of the General Authority for Military Industries of Saudi Arabia (GAMI), reported that local content in defense production rose from 4% in 2018 to nearly 25% in 2024, with a target of 50% by 2030. The defense sector’s workforce grew from 24,000 to 44,000 employees, with 63% being Saudi nationals. During the show, 73 Memorandums of Understanding (MoUs) and 220 other agreements were signed. Major aerospace firms showcased their products: Airbus displayed two A400M transport aircraft, Boeing promoted the F-15EX, and Lockheed Martin featured the F-35 in a flying display. The F-35’s potential acquisition by Saudi Arabia, approved by the Trump administration, was a key focus. The event also included static displays of 63 aircraft, simulators for the F-15EX, and a strong presence of drones and UAVs from countries including South Africa and Ukraine, reflecting the growing importance of unmanned systems following the war in Ukraine. The organizers announced plans to expand the show for its 2028 edition.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 13, 2026 05:59 PM
Source:[aerotime.aero](https://www.aerotime.aero/articles/wds-2026-highlights-saudi-drive-towards-becoming-major-player-in-aerospace)

**'Package Delivered': Macron's Irony and Europe's Move That Surprises Elon Musk**
On February 12, 2026, the European Space Agency launched the Ariane 6 rocket from French Guiana, successfully placing 32 Amazon LEO satellites into low Earth orbit. This marked the first flight of the Ariane 64 configuration, equipped with four boosters and capable of carrying over 20 tons to low Earth orbit—approximately double the capacity of the Ariane 62. French President Emmanuel Macron celebrated the launch on X (formerly Twitter), writing, 'Amazon, your package has been delivered,' calling the mission a 'French achievement' and 'a European success.' The launch was Amazon's first of 18 pre-booked missions on Ariane 6, part of its Project Kuiper initiative, which aims to deploy over 3,200 satellites to compete with Elon Musk’s Starlink. The Ariane 6, developed by ArianeGroup (a joint venture of Airbus and Safran), has completed four successful missions since overcoming a technical issue during its 2024 debut. Amazon has invested at least $10 billion in Project Kuiper and has secured over 100 launch agreements, including with SpaceX, Blue Origin, and Arianespace. However, due to delays in new-generation launch vehicles, Amazon recently requested the FCC extend its deadline to deploy half of its constellation by 2026 to July 2028 or grant a waiver. On the financial front, Amazon's stock declined 2.25% on February 12, 2026, and dropped another 0.63% in after-hours trading, reflecting weak momentum across short-, medium-, and long-term trends according to Benzinga Pro.

Publish date: February 13, 2026 04:31 PM

**Lufthansa Plane with 109 Passengers Makes Emergency Landing in Europe Due to One Passenger's Health Issue**
On February 12, 2026, an Lufthansa Airbus A320neo with 109 passengers departed from Naples, Italy, en route to Munich, Germany. During the flight, one passenger became unwell, prompting cabin crew to provide emergency assistance and notify the captain. The flight crew decided to make an unscheduled emergency landing at Klagenfurt Airport in Austria. The passenger was transferred to medical personnel upon landing; their identity and current health status remain unknown. The aircraft resumed its journey and arrived at Munich with 'minimal delay,' according to Lenta.ru. This incident follows a similar event on the same day, when a passenger jet returning from Glasgow, Scotland, to London, UK, aborted its flight shortly after takeoff after transmitting emergency code 7700.

**4 Key Events That Will Be Important This Week**
Four key economic events are expected to dominate the financial and economic landscape this week, according to Dow Jones Newswires. First, the ZEW Economic Sentiment Index for Germany is projected to rise to 65.0 in February from 59.6 in January, driven by improved industrial order situations in November and December, which boosted investor optimism—evidenced earlier by Sentix's already published index. This event is scheduled for Tuesday, February 17, 2026, at 11:00 CET. Second, investors will closely monitor Airbus's A320 production rate, delivery targets, and expansion plans in Asia, as the company is expected to report a consensus-adjusted EBIT of €7 billion—meeting its 2025 operational forecast—though its free cash flow before customer financing is forecast at €4.29 billion, below the €4.5 billion target. This update is set for Thursday, February 19, 2026, at 06:00 CET. Third, U.S. real GDP growth for the fourth quarter is expected to slow significantly to a year-on-year rate of 1.9%, down from 4.4% in the third quarter, with the level of the same quarter last year surpassed by 1.9% (2.3%). This data will be released on Friday, February 20, 2026, at 14:30 CET. Fourth, the U.S. Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) Deflator is expected to rise 0.3% month-on-month in December, matching November’s 2.8% year-on-year increase. The core PCE inflation (excluding energy and food) is forecast to rise 0.4% monthly and 3.1% annually, up from 2.8% in November, according to Factset. This report will also be released on Friday, February 20, 2026, at 14:30 CET.

**Safran cautious over stepping into Airbus engine dispute with Pratt**
CFM, the joint venture between Safran and GE Aerospace, is cautious about increasing engine deliveries to Airbus beyond agreed volumes, according to Safran CEO Olivier Andries. While CFM is willing to support Airbus if additional engines are needed in 2024, its priority remains fulfilling existing supply commitments. CFM's forecast for a 15% increase in LEAP engine deliveries in 2024 does not include any additional market share expansion. CFM has already secured engine supply agreements with Airbus for 2026. The situation arises amid a stand-off between Airbus and Pratt & Whitney over engine supply, threatening Airbus's production goals. Airbus aims to increase A320neo-family production to 75 aircraft per month by 2027, up from around 60 currently, but has faced delays due to supply chain issues. Airbus reported late deliveries from Pratt & Whitney and has previously cited problems with CFM deliveries. Pratt & Whitney expressed confidence in reaching an agreement, while Airbus declined to comment ahead of its February 19 earnings release.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 13, 2026 08:59 AM
Source:[Market Screener](https://www.marketscreener.com/news/safran-cautious-over-stepping-into-airbus-engine-dispute-with-pratt-ce7e5ddad881f024)

**New Routes & Stronger Economics: Why Air Canada's A350-1000 Order Is A Game Changer**
Air Canada has placed a firm order for eight Airbus A350-1000 jets, with options for eight additional aircraft, marking a pivotal step in its long-haul fleet modernization. First deliveries are expected in the second half of 2040. The A350-1000 offers superior range, payload capacity, and lower unit operating costs compared to older widebody aircraft, enabling Air Canada to profitably launch longer, thinner routes, expand seasonal services, and improve cargo economics. According to Mark Galardo, Air Canada’s Executive Vice President and Chief Commercial Officer, the aircraft will allow the airline to enter new international markets—such as Mumbai from Toronto, potential South African destinations, and additional points in Australia—where ultra-long-haul capabilities are essential. The A350-1000 will also replace aging Boeing 777-300ERs and fill gaps left by the Boeing 787’s limitations on ultra-long sectors. The order fits into a broader, staggered fleet expansion plan: 14 Boeing 787-10s will enter service by late 2026, followed by 30 Airbus A321XLRs (with first deliveries imminent), 23 additional Canadian-built A220s, and five leased Boeing 737 MAX aircraft in 2026. All new aircraft will feature Air Canada’s next-generation cabin standard, upgraded connectivity, and advanced in-flight entertainment. The airline’s hub strategy centers on Toronto Pearson (YYZ), a major global hub serving a multicultural population, with Montreal and Vancouver (YVR) supporting North Atlantic and Asia-Pacific connectivity, respectively. The A350-1000’s entry will enhance Air Canada’s ability to target growing demand from diaspora communities in South and East Asia. Despite current absence in the U.S. market, the aircraft’s role is expected to grow as U.S. carriers gradually adopt it.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 12, 2026 10:10 PM
Source:[Simple Flying](https://simpleflying.com/new-routes-stronger-economics-air-canada-a350-1000-order-game-changer/)

**Air Canada’s Fleet Modernization Continues with A350-1000 Orders for Asia-Pacific Expansion**
Air Canada is continuing its fleet modernization initiative for long-haul aircraft by ordering at least eight Airbus A350-1000s, which can carry over 350 passengers. According to Mark Galardo, Air Canada’s senior vice president and chief commercial officer, the airline’s existing A330s, delivered as early as 1999, will need to be replaced starting in 2029–2030, requiring immediate procurement due to supply chain delays. The A350-1000 will enable Air Canada to fly up to 9,000 nautical miles, offering greater range than the Boeing 787-10 Dreamliner, which can carry about 335 passengers and is also being added to the fleet in 2026. Galardo emphasized that the A350’s extended range will allow Air Canada to launch services to India, a market currently not served, and strengthen its performance in the Asia-Pacific region, where demand is growing. The first deliveries are scheduled from 2030, with options for eight additional A350-1000s. The aircraft offers approximately 25% better fuel efficiency compared to its predecessor. Although the exact order price was not disclosed, the A350-1000’s list price in 2018 was about $336 million USD, though airlines typically receive significant discounts. Air Canada’s stock has declined 1.7% year-to-date on the Toronto Stock Exchange, trading around $19.45 as of February 12, 2026.
Original language: fr
Publish date: February 12, 2026 05:01 PM
Source:[La Presse.ca](https://www.lapresse.ca/affaires/entreprises/2026-02-12/avions-gros-porteurs/la-cure-de-rajeunissement-se-poursuit-chez-air-canada.php)

**Istanbul: 100,000 Employees' Photos Adorn Turkish Airlines' 500th Plane**
Turkish Airlines unveiled its 500th aircraft, a new Airbus A350 named 'TK Aile' or 'Turkish Airlines Family,' during a ceremony at Istanbul Airport on February 12, 2026. The aircraft's exterior features images of 100,000 current and retired company employees, symbolizing 93 years of collective effort and perseverance. According to CEO Ahmet Bozdağ, the fleet expanded from 65 aircraft in 2003 to over 500 by the end of 2025. The airline currently operates flights to 356 destinations across six continents. Bozdağ stated that reaching 500 aircraft was a dream 12 years ago, with a future goal of owning a fleet of 1,000 aircraft by 2036. Turkish Airlines contributed approximately $65 billion to Turkey's economy in 2026 and aims to increase its contribution to $150 billion by 2033.

**Airbus Begins 2026 with 19 Deliveries and 49 New Orders**
Airbus delivered 19 commercial aircraft in January 2026 to 15 different customers, six fewer than in January 2025, with the delivery mix dominated by the A321neo (10 units), followed by the A220-300 (3 units), A320neo (5 units), and one A350-900. Lufthansa and Emirates are reportedly interested in the hypothetical A350-2000, pushing for larger wide-body aircraft. In terms of new orders, Airbus secured 49 commitments in January, all focused on single-aisle aircraft—48 in total—with one double-aisle A330. IAG placed a significant order for 10 aircraft, including 8 A320neo and 2 A321neo. On February 19, 2026, Airbus will release its financial results for 2025 and provide delivery forecasts for the remainder of 2026. These projections are critical for fleet planning, route strategy, and leasing negotiations. For industry executives, they signal confidence in Airbus’s supply chain and market demand; for analysts, they serve as a key indicator of the company’s outlook on industrial resilience and market strength. Additional context includes Saudi Arabia preparing a mega-order for over 150 aircraft, with Boeing and Airbus competing for the deal, and SAS negotiating a large wide-body aircraft order with both manufacturers.
Original language: es
Publish date: February 07, 2026 03:20 PM
Source:[aviacionaldia.com](https://aviacionaldia.com/2026/02/airbus-inicia-2026-con-19-entregas-y-49-nuevos-pedidos.html)

**Airbus Increases Deliveries by 3.5% in 2025 to 793 Aircraft**
Airbus delivered 793 commercial aircraft in 2025 to 91 customers worldwide, representing a 3.5% increase from 766 aircraft delivered in 2024. The company shipped 93 A220 narrow-body jets, 607 A320 family aircraft, 36 A330 wide-body jets, and 57 A350 aircraft. Deliveries slightly exceeded Airbus's revised forecast of 790 (down from an initial 820), though they remained significantly below the pre-pandemic 2019 level of 863 aircraft. Total orders in 2025 reached 1,000, with a net order backlog of 889 aircraft; the total order book stood at 8,754 aircraft by the end of December. Airbus will release its full-year 2025 financial results on February 19. Over the past 12 months, Airbus's market capitalization increased by nearly 40% to €171 billion, outpacing the Stoxx Europe 600 index, which rose about 20%.
Original language: ru
Publish date: January 13, 2026 12:03 PM
Source:[Interfax.ru](https://www.interfax.ru/business/1067367)

**Airbus Delivers 793 Aircraft In 2025 As Order Backlog Reaches Record Level**
Airbus delivered 793 commercial aircraft in 2025 to 91 global customers, exceeding the 766 deliveries in 2024 and 735 in 2023, demonstrating sustained growth amid operational challenges. The A320 Family accounted for 607 deliveries, the A220 Family for 93, the A330 Family for 36, and the A350 Family for 57. The company secured 1,000 new gross orders in 2025, maintaining a book-to-bill ratio above one. As a result, Airbus's order backlog reached a record 8,754 aircraft by the end of 2025, including a historic 1,124 aircraft in the widebody segment. The company celebrated significant deliveries and welcomed new operators for the A220, A321XLR, A330neo, and A350-1000 across various regions, securing repeat orders and attracting new customers. Airbus will release its full-year financial results for 2025 on February 19, 2026.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 12, 2026 10:08 PM
Source:[NASDAQ Stock Market](https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/airbus-delivers-793-aircraft-2025-order-backlog-reaches-record-level)

**Airbus delivers 793 aircraft in 2025 as order backlog reaches record high**
Airbus delivered 793 commercial aircraft to 91 customers worldwide in 2025, a 4% increase compared to 2024, reflecting sustained global demand across its product lineup. The company recorded 1,000 gross orders (889 net) from 57 customers, raising its total order backlog to a record 8,754 aircraft by year-end, including a record 1,124 widebody aircraft backlog. Deliveries were led by single-aisle aircraft, with 607 A320 Family jets and 93 A220s delivered, while widebody deliveries included 36 A330 Family aircraft and 57 A350s. Order intake comprised 49 A220s, 656 A320 Family aircraft, 100 A330neos, two A330 MRTTs, and 193 A350s, demonstrating strong demand across both narrowbody and widebody segments. Airbus welcomed new operators of the A220, A321XLR, A330neo, and A350-1000, secured repeat business, and acquired new customers globally. With a book-to-bill ratio above one and three consecutive years of rising deliveries, Airbus entered 2026 with a robust order book and strong market momentum. Full-year 2025 financial results are scheduled for release on 19 February 2026.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 12, 2026 09:09 PM
Source:[Aviation24.be](https://www.aviation24.be/manufacturers/airbus/airbus-delivers-793-aircraft-in-2025-as-order-backlog-reaches-record-high/)

**Airbus Delivers 793 Commercial Aircraft in 2025, Marking 4% Growth and Record Order Backlog**
Airbus delivered 793 commercial aircraft in 2025 to 91 distinct customers, representing a nearly 4% increase compared to 2024. The A320 family accounted for the largest share of deliveries, with 607 units—up from 602 in 2024 and 571 in 2023. The A220, A350, and A330 followed with 93, 57, and 36 deliveries, respectively. Airbus recorded 1,000 new orders in the segment during the year, and by the end of December 2025, its order backlog reached a record annual high of 8,754 aircraft, 'evidencing strong market demand for Airbus's product portfolio,' according to the company. The company emphasized that deliveries in 2025 maintained an upward trajectory despite a complex and dynamic operating environment, marked by historic deliveries and the entry of new operators for the A220, A321XLR, A330neo, and A350-1000 across all regions. Recurring orders and new customers were observed for both single-aisle and wide-body aircraft, with the wide-body backlog reaching a record annual high of 1,124 aircraft. Airbus's financial results for 2025 will be released on February 19.

**Airbus Reveals 2025's commercial aircraft deliveries - Focus on Travel News**
Airbus delivered 793 commercial aircraft to 91 customers globally in 2025, registering 1,000 new gross orders in its Commercial Aircraft business. The backlog at the end of December 2025 reached a record high of 8,754 aircraft, reflecting strong market demand for Airbus' product portfolio. The company achieved a book-to-bill ratio above one, indicating sustained order momentum. Deliveries continued to trend upward despite a complex and dynamic operating environment. Key milestones included landmark deliveries of the A220, A321XLR, A330neo, and A350-1000 to new operators across all regions. The widebody backlog reached a year-end record of 1,124 aircraft, driven by repeat orders and new customers in both single-aisle and widebody segments. Airbus' full-year financial results for 2025 are scheduled for release on 19 February 2026.

**Airbus Delivers 793 Aircraft in 2025, Exceeding Revised Target Despite Quality Challenges**
Airbus delivered 793 commercial aircraft in 2025, a 4% increase from the 766 delivered in 2024, and slightly exceeded its revised 2025 target of 790 aircraft, which had been lowered from an initial goal of 820 due to quality issues with fuselage panels on its A320 model. Despite this improvement, deliveries in 2025 remain below the pre-pandemic benchmark of 863 aircraft in 2019. The company reported 1,000 gross orders and 889 net orders for the year. Boeing, which has not yet released its full-year 2025 results, delivered 537 aircraft between January and November 2025, placing Airbus ahead by nearly 260 units. Airbus noted that the operational environment remained 'complex and dynamic' but confirmed it slightly surpassed its revised target. Airbus will publish its full annual results on February 19, 2026.

**Airbus: Deliveries Rise 4% in 2025 Amid Complex Operating Environment**
Airbus reported that its aircraft deliveries increased by 4% in 2025, exceeding its revised target of approximately 790 aircraft, which had been lowered from an earlier forecast of 820. The company confirmed it received 1,000 gross orders and 889 net orders during the year. In 2024, Airbus delivered 766 aircraft, up from 735 in 2023. The company warned that the operating environment remains 'complex and dynamic.' Boeing, set to release its annual results on Tuesday, delivered 537 aircraft between January and November. Airbus will publish its own annual results on February 19, 2026.
